title-group.article-title: Novelistic Interpretation: The Traveling Theory of Lukács's "Theory of the Nove"

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2009 JNT: Journal of Narrative Theory

ref.mixed-citation: Kyung Hee University Research Fund in 2008 (KHU-20080689)
Marxist "trans- lation" of the Kantian formulation of the insurmountable gap of the subject-object re- lationship presented in the work The Theory of the Novel
History and Class Conscious- ness (1923)
Theodor Adorno's The Philosophy of New Music from 1948
Frantz Fanon's The Wretched of the Earth from 1961

John K. Noyes has argued, Said's emphasis on traveling adds a crucially geographical or spatial dimension to a given theoretical dis- course, a spatial displacement which may "set a dialogue in motion between the place of its articulation and its transcendence of place" (350)

Sara Nadal-Melsió writes, "The radicalization of [Lukács's] aesthetic categories cannot be separated from a strategic and necessary political radicalization . . . If his- torical urgency cannot justify Lukács's oversimplifications, it at least explains and contextualizes them" (66)
Arpad Kadarkay's Georg Lukács and Mary Gluck's "Towards a Historical Definition of Modernism."
Colin Davis's After Poststructuralism
Jonathan Culler's The Lit- erary in Theory
Journal of Narrative Theory, "Real- ism in Retrospect,"
Matthew Beaumont's edited collection Adventures in Realism

Lukács writes that there are two primary dangers of the novel's aesthetic strategy: "ei- ther the fragility of the world may manifest itself so crudely that it will cancel out the immanence of meaning which the form demands, or else the longing for the disso- nance to be resolved, affirmed and absorbed into the work may be so great that it will lead to a premature closing of the circle of the novel's world, causing the form to dis- integrate into disparate, heterogeneous parts" (Theory 71-72).
Lukács later will argue in The Histor- ical Novel (published in 1937)
Fredric Jame- son's Althusserian notion of history or totality as a "lack" or an "absent cause" [39]
Jameson's Marxism and Form for a reading of Theory of the Novel (160-205)
The Political Unconscious, where Jameson reads the Lukácsian conception of to- tality in terms of the Althusserian notion of History as an "absent cause" (39)
Susan Derwin's The Ambivalence of Form
J. M. Bernstein's The Philosophy of the Novel

Jameson, in his reading of Theory of the Novel, evocatively writes, "a hybrid form which must be reinvented at every moment of its development. Each novel is a process in which the very possibility of narration must begin in a void, without any acquired momentum: its privileged subject matter will therefore be the search, in a world in which neither goals nor paths are established beforehand" (Marxism 172)

Fredric Jameson's The Political Unconscious: "the aesthetic act is... ideological, and the production of aesthetic or narrative form is to be seen as an ideological act in its own right, with the function of inventing imagi- nary or formal 'solutions' to unresolvable social contradictions" (64)
Bernstein's words, "a dialectic of interpretation and representation" (xviii)
Villanueva 28-31
Lukács's view, "The novel is the epic of a world that has been abandoned by God" (Theory 88)

"become demons; their power is effective and alive, but it no longer penetrates the world, or does not yet do so: the world has a co- herence of meaning, a causality, which is incomprehensible to the vital, effective force of a god-become-demon; from the demon's viewpoint, the affairs of such a world ap- pear purely senseless" (86-87)
Bernstein for a more elaborate discussion of the two different ironic strategies in The Theory (216-220)
Lukács's "need for reflexion" and Said's own notion of "molestation" (107-108)

"critique of the representational as natural, is already implicit in the Lukácsean realist map. What, in the last instance, expels modernism from the map is not what it is (self- conscious) but what it is not: relational, ethical, and 'narrative' in Lukics's sense" (79n)
Eva Corredor's György Lukács and the Literary Pretext
Bernstein's Philosophy of the Novel

Lukács argues, it must prescribe "still stricter, still more inviolable artistic laws for itself" than other art forms, and "these laws are the more binding, the more indefinable and unformulable" (Theory 73-74)
Lukács later criticized naturalism and modernism (Theory 76)
"light upon a state of affairs which is necessarily present at all times and everywhere" (77)
"revealed again and again as illusory" (77)
Brooks argues, is the "anticipation of ret- rospection," the expectation of a narrative end that "can finally determine meaning, close the sentence as a signifying totality" (22-23)

"the thread upon which the whole world of the novel is strung and along which it unrolls, but... this development acquires significance only because it is typical of that system of ideas and experienced ideals which regulatively determines the inner and outer world of the novel" (Theory 82-83)

Lukács's narrative dynamic: "A story is made out of events to the extent that plot makes events into a story. The plot, therefore, places us at the crossing point of temporality and narrativity" (167)
Brian Richardson's Unlikely Stories
Christopher Prendergast's Peirce-inspired critique of causality in The Order ofMimesis (45-49)

David Hume's famous argument that "causality is a concept derived from experience, in which we observe that one type of event always seems to precede another certain type, so that later, when we observe again one of the former types, we then infer that the latter type will occur" (151)

Naomi Schor's article "Fiction as Interpretation," in which she encourages one to view interpretation "not as something that is done to fiction but rather as some- thing that is done in fiction" (168)
Fredric Jameson refers to as "national allegory" in the non-western text. After having analysed, in the work The Political Unconscious
"Third- World Literature" 69
Timothy Bewes' article "The Novel as an Absence: Lukács and the Event of Postmodern Fiction" for a discussion of forms of de-reified temporal experience in Theory of the Novel
Sigmund Freud's "Remembering, Repeating, and Working-Through" (147-156)
Slavoj Žižek's The Sublime Object of Ideology (55-84)
Brooks' Reading for the Plot (90-112)
Studies in European Literature 86
Writer and Critic 34-35
Meaning of Contemporary Realism 99

Harry Shaw observes, "a selection of reality, not its mere 'transparent' replication. Yet, as part of his inheritance from German romantic aesthetics, he sometimes makes it seem as if he's offering an aesthetics of transparency, in suggesting that though works of art are really necessarily selective, they must seem to readers to leave no gaps" (13n)
Meaning of Contemporary Real- ism 120
"will wither away, as the literary forms of feudalism have withered away" (115)
Lukács in "Reconciliation under Duress" (151-176)
Eric Downing's Double Exposures (7-14)

John Frow, "Lukács is thinking in terms of a spiralling historical move- ment. Thus each phase is at once progressive and yet runs parallel to a previous phase ... This may go some way toward explaining what is apparently a failure of historical awareness in Lukács's work, his absolutization of a particular form of the novel as an ahistorical model of realism" (10)
Nadal-Melsió likewise argues that "Lukács's [realist] theories explore the lack implicit in contemporary modernism and the promise implicit in nineteenth-century realism,"
Lukács was "forced to reread Balzac and Tolstoy rather than look for their 'heirs'" (83, 81)

Frow rightly points out, "In the later Lukács the notion of historical recurrence seems increasingly to have led him to ignore the moment of negativity he had recog- nized in the novel. History itself loses its uncertainty and its formlessness ... An ethi- cal-aesthetic valuation (realism/decadence) replaces the morally neutral categories of The Theory of the Novel, and the bourgeois historical novel becomes . . . a new mani- festation of wholeness . . . [But] if novelists can no longer discover meaning, this is nevertheless primarily a moral failing on their part, not the result of an objective social process" (11)
Stuart Sims' words, "the theory-wielding critic has edged ahead of the author" (44)

Hall writes, "It is certainly the case that artworks point towards utopia for Adorno, but they do this only negatively . . . They do not so much provide a glimpse of a meaningful world... as negate the idea that the present world is the only possible world" (156)

Frow has argued, "Literature is not a conventional order of discourse; rather, lit- erary reality is immediately identical with reality itself . . . literature is based on the iconic sign: it is natural, motivated, mirroring a sense which is independent of its in- terpretation" (15)
Regarding Lukács's rejection of vulgar materialism and the notion of a simple causal relationship between base and superstructure, see Writer and Critic [62-66]
Adams, Jon-K. "Causality and Narrative." Journal of Literary Semantics 18.3 (1989): 149-162.
Adorno, Theodor W. "Reconciliation under Duress." Aesthetics and Politics. Ed. and trans. Ronald Taylor. London: Verso, 1977. 151-176.
Beaumont, Matthew, ed. Adventures in Realism. Malden, MA: Blackwell, 2007.
Bernstein, J. M. The Philosophy of the Novel: Lukács, Marxism and the Dialectics of Form. Minneapolis: U of Minnesota P, 1984.
Bewes, Tímothy. "The Novel as an Absence: Lukács and the Event of Postmodern Fic- tion." Novel: A Forum on Fiction 38.1 (2004): 5-20.
Brecht, Bertolt. "Against Georg Lukács." Aesthetics and Politics. Ed. and trans. Ronald Taylor. London: Verso, 1977. 68-85.
Brooks, Peter. Reading for the Plot: Design and Intention in Narrative. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1984.
Carroll, David. "Representations or the End(s) of History: Dialectics and Fiction." Yale French Studies 59 (1980): 201-229.
Culler, Jonathan. The Literary in Theory. Stanford: Stanford UP, 2007.
Cunningham, David. "After Adorno: The Narrator of the Contemporary European Novel." Adorno and Literature. Ed. David Cunningham and Nigel Mapp. London: Contin- uum, 2006. 188-200.
Currie, Mark. About Time. Edinburgh: Edinburgh UP, 2007.
Davis, Colin. After Poststructuralism: Reading, Stories and Theory. London: Routledge, 2004.
de Man, Paul. "Georg Lukács's Theory of the Novel." Blindness and Insight: Essays in the Rhetoric of Contemporary Criticism. 2nd ed. London: Methuen, 1983.
Derwin, Susan. The Ambivalence of Form: Lukács, Freud, and the Novel. Baltimore: John Hopkins UP, 1992.
Downing, Eric. Double Exposures: Repetition and Realism in Nineteenth-Century German Fiction. Stanford: Stanford UP, 2000.

Freud, Sigmund. "Remembering, Repeating and Working-Through." The Standard Edition of the Complete Psychological Works of Sigmund Freud. Vol. 12. Trans. James Stra- chey. London: Hogarth, 1958. 147-156.
Frow, John. Marxism and Literary History. Cambridge: Harvard UP, 1986.
Gluck, Mary. "Towards a Historical Definition of Modernism: Georg Lukács and the Avant-Garde." The Journal of Modern History 58.4 (1986): 845-882.
Hall, Timothy. "Adorno's Aesthetic Theory and Lukics's Theory of the Novel." Adorno and Literature. Ed. David Cunningham and Nigel Mapp. London: Continuum, 2006. 145-58.
Jameson, Frederic. Marxism and Form: Twentieth-Century Dialectic Theories of Litera- ture. Princeton: Princeton UP, 1971.
---. The Political Unconscious: Narrative as a Socially Symbolic Act. London: Rout- ledge, 2002.
---. "Third-World Literature in the Era of Multinational Capitalism." Social Text 15 (1986): 65-88.
Kadarkay, Arpad. Georg Lukdcs--Life, Thought, and Politics. Cambridge, MA: Basil Blackwell, 1991.
Lukács, Georg. History and Class Consciousness-Studies in Marxist Dialectics. Trans. Rodney Livingstone. London: Merlin, 1990.
---. The Meaning of Contemporary Realism. Trans. John and Necke Mander. London: Merlin, 1979.
---. Studies in European Realism. Trans. Edith Bone. London: Merlin, 1989.
---. The Theory of the Novel. Trans. Anna Bostock. London: Merlin, 2003.
---. Writer and Critic. Trans. Arthur Kahn. London: Merlin, 1978.
Nadal-Melsió, Sara. "Georg Lukics: Magus Realismus?" Diacritics 34:2 (2004): 62-84.
Prendergast, Christopher. The Order of Mimesis: Balzac, Stendhal, Nerval, Flaubert. Cam- bridge: Cambridge UP, 1986.
---. The Triangle of Representation. New York: Columbia UP, 2000.
Realism in Retrospect. Ed. Abby Coykendall and Audre Jaffe. Spec. Issue of JNT 38.1 (Winter 2008).
Richardson, Brian. Unlikely Stories: Causality and the Nature of Modern Literature. Newark: U of Delaware P, 1997.
Ricoeur, Paul. "Narrative Time." On Narrative. Ed. W. J. T. Mitchell. Chicago: U of Chicago P, 1981. 165-186.
Said, Edward W. Beginnings: Intention and Method. New York: Basic, 1975.
---. "Traveling Theory." The World, the Text and the Critic. Cambridge: Harvard UP, 1983. 226-248.
---. "Traveling Theory Reconsidered." Reflections on Exile and Other Literary and Cultural Essays. London: Granta, 2001. 436-52.

Schor, Naomi. "Fiction as Interpretation/ Interpretation as Fiction." The Reader in the Text: Essays on Audience and Interpretation. Ed. Susan S. Suleiman and Inge Crosman. Princeton: Princeton UP, 1980. 165-82.
Shaw, Harry E. Narrating Reality-Austen, Scott, Eliot. Ithaca, New York: Cornell UP, 1999.
Sims, Stuart. Georg Lukács. Hemel Hempstead: Harvester Wheatsheaf, 1994.
Villanueva, Darío. Theories of Literary Realism. Trans. Mihai I. Spariosu and Santiago García-Castañón. New York: State U of New York P, 1997.
